Award.AwardTitle: Multi-resolution framework for the characterization of protein mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Prof. Cecilia Clementi of Rice University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry to develop multiscale protein models and new strategies to explore complex free energy landscapes. This project uses coarse graining as the starting point to develop multi-resolution protein models, which are combined with a theoretically robust framework involving a supersymmetric generalization of the Fokker-Planck diffusion equation, and a mathematically rigorous definition of collective variables. These methods are applied to rapidly locate rare event regions in molecular dynamics landscapes, and give a robust foundation for benchmarking and creating new models of complex systems. The developed methodology is used to characterize the functional aspects of protein dynamics on timescales out of reach to conventional approaches.

The broader impacts of this research are in the biological sciences. Prof. Clementi is involved with the development of courses in computational molecular biology and an outreach program involving presentations to local schools.

This project is co-funded by the Molecular Biophysics program in Division of Molecular and Cellular Biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF grant CHE-1152344 has supported the definition and application of models that can span a broad region of a protein?s configurational space to first perform a coarser exploration and map the relevant regions, then concentrate a finer analysis on the areas of interests. We have focused along four interconnected lines. We briefly comment on the main outcomes below.

 

Coarse-grained models to study long-timescale dynamics of large protein complexes

Modern experimental techniques characterize the dynamics of macromolecular assemblies either focusing on a few atoms (e.g, single molecule techniques) or considering larger resolutions (e.g., super-resolution microscopy localization techniques) over long timescales. All-atom simulations provide fine-detail information (ca. 1 nm) up to a few 100 microseconds timescale. Our work allows to define multiscale models to bridge the gap between these techniques to target an intermediate resolution (ca. 0.5-20 nm) over a broad range of timescales (ns to s), providing crucial components in the understanding of biological processes. We have created a suite of programs that allows us to simulate proteins at different resolutions, spanning from models representing a residue by a single “bead” centered on the Carbon- α atom, to higher resolution models that include all atomic coordinates. Different forms for the effective interaction potentials can be used for each resolution. Previous models proposed by our group and others have been included in our repertoire (e.g., the DMC model, see PNAS 29, 10141 (2005), and the AWSEM-MD model, see J. Phys. Chem. B 116, 8494 (2012)). We have a GitHub project collecting the software, that will be released soon.

Techniques to incorporate experimental data into a coarse-grained protein model

Oftentimes, for a biological process of interest, an abundance of structural, thermodynamical, or kinetic measurements is available at least for parts of the biomolecules involved. The structural information per se is incomplete as the macromolecules involved are often partly disordered and/or change configurations. Simulations can, in principle, resolve details not accessible to experiment, but are based on empirical models and, alone, cannot be quantitatively predictive. We have developed a theoretical framework able to integrate the available experimental information for a given molecular process over a multiple range of time- and length-scales into coarse-grained models, to fully exploit the complementary information that can be obtained in theory and experiment and advance significantly our understanding of macromolecular dynamics and function. While we first proposed a preliminary approach in this direction about 10 years ago (see JMB 343, 235 (2004) and JMB 363, 297 (2006)), we have more recently reformulated this problem in the more general framework of Baysian inference. We have two publications in preparation demonstrating the power of this new approach.

Adaptive sampling methods

Even when using coarse-grained models, molecular simulations of large molecules can be computationally demanding. We have developed and applied adaptive sampling methods to speed up the exploration of the conformational space of complex molecules, and the calculation of the equilibrium values of physical observables to be compared with experimental data. We have recently proposed an adaptive sampling approach that has been shown to speed up significantly (2-3 orders of magnitude) the sampling of complex configurational spaces (see, e.g., J. Phys. Chem. B 117, 12769 (2013), and PCCP 16, 19181 (2014)). The approach is based on the on-the-fly identification of slow coordinates, that can in turn be used to iteratively redistribute the starting points of large ensembles of short trajectories to boost the occurrence of rare events. The fundamental tools for the determination of reaction coordinates from molecular dynamics data have also been developed with the support of this award (see, e.g., J. Chem. Phys. 134, 124116 (2011), J. Chem. Phys. 134, 144109 (2011), J. Phys. Chem. B 115, 13065 (2013), Annu. Rev. Phys. Chem. 64, 295 (2013), J. Chem. Phys. 139, 145102 (2013), JCTC 11, 5947-5960 (2015), JCTC 11, 5002 (2015)).

Applications

The methodological results described above have been combined in applications to relevant protein systems. For instance, we have combined the use of coarse-grained and all-atom molecular simulation with adaptive sampling techniques to characterize the functional intermediate in the photocycle of the Photoactive Yellow Protein (PYP), that was still elusive to experiment alone or different simulation techniques (see Figure). 
Other relevant applications completed with this award include the study of the O2 migration in hemoglobin (see J. Chem. Phys. 142, 025103 (2015)), and the the characterization of a peptide used in a metallopeptide catalyst (see Chem. Sci. 5, 1401 (2014)).
